A YouTube spokesperson told TechCrunch that the feature is available to select creators as a part […]

item.title: From Skims to Stripe, here are the startups that are likely — or definitely — not having IPOs this year

item.description:
Last year’s investor dreams of a strong 2024 IPO pipeline have faded, if not fully disappeared, as we settle in to the second half of the year. item.description:
Techstars is cutting 17% of its staff and will end its $80 million J.P. Morgan-backed AdvancingCities program once the fund is completely deployed.

item.description:

item.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 tech layoffs
item.dc:creator: Cody Corrall, Alyssa Stringer
item.description:
The tech layoff wave is still going strong in 2024. Following significant workforce reductions in 2022 and 2023, this year has already seen 60,000 job cuts across 254 companies, according to independent layoffs tracker Layoffs.fyi. Companies like Tesla, Amazon, Google, TikTok, Snap and Microsoft have conducted sizable layoffs in the first months of 2024. Smaller-sized […]

item.title: This Week in AI: OpenAI’s talent retention woes

item.description:
Hiya, folks, welcome to TechCrunch’s regular AI newsletter. This week in AI, OpenAI lost another co-founder. John Schulman, who played a pivotal role in the development of ChatGPT, OpenAI’s AI-powered chatbot platform, has left the company for rival Anthropic. Schulman announced the news on X, saying that his decision stemmed from a desire to deepen […]

item.title: TechCrunch Minute: Is AI actually making workers more productive?
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description:
Is AI going to make us all more productive at work? Executives are feeling optimistic, but workers aren’t quite as convinced. That’s according to a new study from freelancing marketplace Upwork. item.description:

item.title: After EU approval, UK clears HPE’s $14B Juniper Networks acquisition
item.dc:creator: Paul Sawers
item.description:
Hewlett Packard Enterprise's (HPE) planned $14 billion acquisition of Juniper Networks is one step closer to completion — the U.K.'s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has confirmed that the deal won't face any further scrutiny.
